comment.author: 18532986@N07
comment._content: I'm almost positive that this is the USS Indianapolis (CA-35), a light cruiser. It may be the USS Portland (CA-33) though.

comment.author: 12814971@N00
comment._content: CA- heavy cruiser. Could be either Indianapolis or Portland. Both were in the Pacific in 1941, and the DANFS is a little vague about precise whereabouts. Indianapolis went on the become flagship for Admiral Ray Spruance when he was commanding 5th fleet.

comment.author: 9881232@N02
comment._content: That's the USS Chicago.  When the ship was lost in January 1943, they tried to suppress the news at first.  Many people in Brisbane remembered the  March 1941 visit and felt a real sense of loss because they had met and in many cases given hospitality to the sailors during that earlier visit.

comment.author: 94956239@N05
comment._content: Read more about this image on the John Oxley Library blog blogs.slq.qld.gov.au/jol/2013/07/30/brisbane-rejoices-as-...

comment.author: 12814971@N00
comment._content: Almost has to be Portland, not Chicago. The bridge is a dead givaway. Here's Chicago's bridge: (after being rammed by a tanker in 1933) and here's Portland. the bridge is unmistakable. And finally, see another discussion of this picture www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05/7437763642/

comment.author: 32605636@N06
comment._content: IT certainly takes an expert view and close examination of the ships to see the differences, although tit does look, from comparing these photographs that the bridge is much more like the Portland. We'll also check contemporary newspapers to see how the event was recorded in the paper.

comment.author: 32605636@N06
comment._content: An extensive report in the Brisbane newspaper of the time notes that there were seven ships visiting Australia and New Zealand at the time. You can read it here: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article98260728 or see the original article at this link. Does it answer the question of which ship? Don't think so, except it does state that both the Portland and the Chicago were in Brisbane at that time. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/printArticleJpg/98260728/3?print=n

comment.author: 12814971@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryqueensland] No firm conclusions from the article, that's for sure. I'm going to stick with Portland, however. That bridge pretty much seals the deal. The article is interesting- Col. Knox (Frank Knox, US Secretary of the Navy, July, 1940-August, 1944) was being a bit optimistic in his estimate of the March, 1941 U.S.Navy, although by 1943, and certainly 1944, there was no argument on the topic.
